This one is really useful: where to put your commonly used modules, so that you don't need to take a copy every time you use them - fantastic.  BTW, for Mac users, the following Terminal command tells you where your site-packages directory lives: python3 -m site --user-site (it works on my MacBook Air, anyway).

author: @kolchosenpunk2751
text: Different solution: Create an empty file called "SomePath.pth" in the directory where you installed Python. Then add the path into your "SomePath.pth"-file (e.g. C:\Users\YourName\Testscripts). You can add additional pathes by simply adding a new path in a new line. Following my solution you won't have to copy your files which can be practical if your .py-files are stored in entirely different directories. Caution: said solution won't work if you run your project on a different machine! In this case you'll have to put the files into one and the same directory or create empty __init__.py-files in your project-directory and all your subdirectories if you have any.

author: @sentdex
text: +Luke Paul ... for some reason I cannot respond to your comment directly, but... Most setup.py commands really are just sending the script to your site-packages, so you can indeed actually just download the module and do it yourself. A lot of modules have folders full of various scripts, which are full of functions, but you can usually just download the source and move the whole thing yourself. Great question!

author: @Cal97g
text: They don't need to be 'installed' - they can just be included from the same directory. However, 'installing' them makes them accessible by every python program from one location. I.E you don't need a copy in the root directory of every program that needs to use it.

author: @Ps5GamerUk
text: Question from a newbie; why do third party modules need to be 'installed' if they are just scripts? Why can they not just be placed in the site-packages directory and imported?
